Condition 1 tells us Mary buys three bags. Condition 2 states the first bag has 7930843 M&Ms. Since Condition 3 says the second bag has 12 more M&Ms than the first one, the second bag has 7930843 + 12 = 7930855 M&Ms. Lastly, according to Condition 4, the third bag has half as many M&Ms as the first bag, which makes it 7930843 / 2 = 3965421.5. Since we can't have half a bag, this calculation suggests that Mary either received an incorrect amount or there was a mistake in the problem statement. To determine the actual number of M&Ms Mary received, disregard the information about the third bag, since the conditions do not provide valid data for it.

So, based on the information provided, Mary received 7930843 M&Ms.
